#Text=IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT'S NOSE BECOMES OUTRAGEOUSLY LONG
#Text=The next morning
#Text=poor , jaded , famished Passepartout said to himself that he must get something to eat at all hazards , and the sooner he did so the better .
#Text=He might , indeed , sell his watch ; but he would have starved first .
#Text=Now or never he must use the strong , if not melodious voice which nature had bestowed upon him .

#Text=He knew several French and English songs , and resolved to try them upon the Japanese , who must be lovers of music , since they were for ever pounding on their cymbals , tam-tams , and tambourines , and could not but appreciate European talent .

#Text=It was , perhaps , rather early in the morning to get up a concert , and the audience prematurely aroused from their slumbers , might not possibly pay their entertainer with coin bearing the Mikado 's features .
#Text=Passepartout therefore decided to wait several hours ; and , as he was sauntering along , it occurred to him that he would seem rather too well dressed for a wandering artist .
#Text=The idea struck him to change his garments for clothes more in harmony with his project ; by which he might also get a little money to satisfy the immediate cravings of hunger .
#Text=The resolution taken , it remained to carry it out .
#Text=It was only after a long search that Passepartout discovered a native dealer in old clothes , to whom he applied for an exchange .
#Text=The man liked the European costume , and ere long Passepartout issued from his shop accoutred in an old Japanese coat , and a sort of one-sided turban , faded with long use .
#Text=A few small pieces of silver , moreover , jingled in his pocket .
#Text=" Good ! " thought he .
#Text=" I will imagine I am at the Carnival ! "

#Text=His first care , after being thus " Japanesed , " was to enter a tea-house of modest appearance , and , upon half a bird and a little rice , to breakfast like a man for whom dinner was as yet a problem to be solved .
#Text=" Now , " thought he , when he had eaten heartily , " I must n't lose my head .

#Text= The United States ! " said Passepartout ;

column1: #Text=" that 's just what I want ! "
#Text=He followed the clown , and soon found himself once more in the Japanese quarter .

#Text=A quarter of an hour later he stopped before a large cabin , adorned with several clusters of streamers , the exterior walls of which were designed to represent , in violent colours and without perspective , a company of jugglers .
#Text=This was the Honourable William Batulcar 's establishment .

#Text=That gentleman was a sort of Barnum , the director of a troupe of mountebanks , jugglers , clowns , acrobats , equilibrists , and gymnasts , who , according to the placard , was giving his last performances before leaving the Empire of the Sun for the States of the Union .
#Text=Passepartout entered and asked for Mr. Batulcar , who straightway appeared in person .
#Text=" What do you want ? " said he to Passepartout , whom he at first took for a native .
#Text=" Would you like a servant , sir ? " asked Passepartout .
#Text=" A servant ! " cried Mr. Batulcar , caressing the thick grey beard which hung from his chin .

#Text=" I already have two who are obedient and faithful , have never left me , and serve me for their nourishment and here they are , " added he , holding out his two robust arms , furrowed with veins as large as the strings of a bass-viol .
#Text=" So I can be of no use to you ? "
#Text=" None . "
#Text=" The devil !

#Text= Ah ! " said the Honourable Mr. Batulcar .

#Text= A man dresses as he can . "

column1: #Text=" That 's true .
#Text=" Then you ought to know how to make grimaces ? "

#Text=" Why , " replied Passepartout , a little vexed that his nationality should cause this question , " we Frenchmen know how to make grimaces , it is true but not any better than the Americans do . "
